section.title: Mathematical Models: A Catalog of Essential Functions

ul.li: Identify the basic characteristics of essential functions, including: domain, range, end behavior, roots, asymptotes, x- and y-intercepts, slope, symmetry.

subsubsection.title: Linear Functions
subsubsection.p:
Remember that a linear function requires two pieces of information- a starting value (b, the y-intercept), and an amount of incremental change in the independent variable (m, the slope of the function). This gives us three ways to describe a linear function:
Verbally: A function with a constant rate of change
Graphically: They are straight lines
Algebraically: f(x) = mx+b

question.statement: Given two points (x_1,y_1) and (x_2,y_2), how can we find the slope of the line between them?

example.statement:
The following table gives the percentage of new companies which remained open t years after beginning business.
Years After Opening
5
6
7
8
9
10
Companies Still Open (in %)
50
47
44
41
38
35
Plot the points on the graph below
A blank graph to plot the points
\begin{tikzpicture} \begin{axis}[ width = .8\textwidth, height = 4in, grid = both, axis x line = bottom, axis y line = left, every axis y label/.style={at={(ticklabel cs:1.1)}}, y label style={at={(axis description cs:.0,1.1)},anchor=north}, ylabel = {$C(t)$}, every axis x label/.style= {at ={(ticklabel cs:1)}}, x label style={at={(axis description cs:1.1,0)},anchor=east}, xlabel = {$t$}, xmin=3, xmax = 13, xtick = {3,4,...,12}, ymin=30, ymax = 55, minor y tick num = 4, ]
\end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}
Use the data to find an equation for the line between these points.
Use the equation in (b) to write a linear model for the percentage of new companies remaining open, t years after beginning business.

subsubsection.title: Polynomials
subsubsection.definition:
Polynomial Polynomial
A function P is called a polynomial if
P(x) = a_nx^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdots + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0

image.description: The graph of a linear function with positive leading coefficient. The line goes up left to right.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {x}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of a linear function with negative leading coefficient. The line goes down left to right.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {-1*x}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of a quadratic function with positive leading coefficient. The curve goes down until it reaches a vertex, then turns back upward.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {x^2}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of a quadratic function with negative leading coefficient. The curve goes up until it reaches a vertex, then turns back downward.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = center, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {-1*x^2}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of a cubic function with positive leading coefficient. The curve begins going upward, slows down to be flat for a moment, then turns back upward.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {x^3}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of a cubic function with negative leading coefficient. The curve begins going downward, slows down to be flat for a moment, then turns back downward.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[domain = -1:1] {-1*x^3}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of an even function with positive leading coefficient. The curve goes begins moving upward and ends moving downward; the behavior in the middle depends on the function.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[<-,domain = -1:-.75] {x^2}; \addplot[domain = -.75:.75, dotted] {x^2}; \addplot[domain = .75:1,->] {x^2}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of an even function with negative leading coefficient. The curve goes begins moving downward and ends moving upward; the behavior in the middle depends on the function.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[<-,domain = -1:-.75] {-1*x^2}; \addplot[domain = -.75:.75, dotted] {-1*x^2}; \addplot[domain = .75:1,->] {-1*x^2}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of an odd function with positive leading coefficient. The curve goes begins moving upward and ends moving upward; the behavior in the middle depends on the function.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[<-,domain = -1:-.75] {x^3}; \addplot[domain = -.75:.75, dotted] {x^3}; \addplot[domain = .75:1,->] {x^3}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

image.description: The graph of an odd function with negative leading coefficient. The curve goes begins moving downward and ends moving downward; the behavior in the middle depends on the function.
image.latex-image: \begin{tikzpicture}\begin{axis}[scale = .25, axis x line = middle, axis y line = middle, ticks = none] \addplot[<-,domain = -1:-.75] {-1*x^3}; \addplot[domain = -.75:.75, dotted] {-1*x^3}; \addplot[domain = .75:1,->] {-1*x^3}; \end{axis} \end{tikzpicture}

subsubsection.title: Other Functions

definition.title: Exponential/Logarithmic Function
definition.p: An exponential function is a function of the form f(x)=b^x, where the base b is a positive constant.
A logarithmic function is a function of the form f(x)=log_b x, where the base b is a positive constant.

subsubsection.p: Exponential and logarithmic functions have these properties:

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find an equation for the family of linear functions with slope -1, and sketch a few members of the family.
Find an equation for the family of linear functions such that f(2) = 1, and sketch a few members of the family.
Which function belongs to both families?

example.statement: Find an expression for a cubic function f if f(1) = 6, and f(-1) = f(0) = f(2) = 0.

The monthly cost of driving a car depends on the number of miles driven. Casey found that in April, it cost her $350 to drive 450 miles, and in June, it cost her $460 to drive 800 miles.
Express the monthly cost C as a function of the distance driven (d), assuming that a linear relationship gives a suitable model.
Use (a) to predict the cost of driving 1500 miles per month.
Sketch the graph of the linear function. What does the slope represent? Include units.
What does the C-intercept represent?
Why does a linear function give a suitable model in this situation?

subsubsection.title: Power Functions
subsubsection.definition:
Power Function Power Function
A power function is any function of the form x^a, where a is a constant.

example.statement: Describe the difference between a power function and a polynomial.

Give an example function for each class of power function below, and give a real-world situation which might use that function.
A power function with a \gt 0.
A power function where a is not an integer.
A power function where a \lt 0.

definition.title: Rational Function
definition.p: A rational function is a ratio of two polynomials, written as f(x) = \dfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)}, where P(x) and Q(x) are polynomials.
The domain of a rational function consists of all values x such that Q(x)\neq 0.

subsubsection.title: Algebraic Functions
subsubsection.definition:
Algebraic Function Algebraic Function
A function f is called an algebraic function if it can be constructed using algebraic operations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and taking roots.

question.statement: Of the types of functions we have seen so far, which are algebraic? Which are not?

example.statement: Write an example of an algebraic function using at least one of each type of function we have covered so far.

subsubsection.title: Trigonometric Functions

image.description: A right triangle with angle x, with hypotenuse labeled hyp, opposite side labeled opp, and adjacent labeled adj.

subsubsection.p: Here are some useful properties of trigonometric functions

example.statement: Give an example of a real-world situation which might be modeled with a sine or cosine function. Justify your response.
Sketch the graph of each trig function over one period. If necessary, sketch any asymptotes the graph has.
Find the domain of the function f(x) = \dfrac{3}{2\sin x + 1}, first on the interval [0,2\pi), then in general.

Ecologists have modeled the relationship between the area of a region and the number of species inhabiting the region. In particular, the number of species S of bats living in and around Austin has been related to the surface area A of the structure by the equation S = 0.3A^{0.5}.
A structure near I-35 has a surface area A = 10000 m^2; how many species of bat do you expect to find on the structure?
If an overpass has nine species of bats, estimate the area of overpass.
